stem: A 32-year-old client with bipolar disorder is admitted after spending the day working outdoors in 98°F heat. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute mental status changes following heat exposure.
Background: Taking Lithium Carbonate 450mg BID. Athlete and landscaper.
Assessment: Client is dizzy, reporting severe nausea, and has visible coarse hand tremors.
Recommendation: Fluid resuscitation and lithium level check.

tabs.title: Environmental Exposure & Fluid Log
tabs.content:
AssessmentFindingInterpretation

Serum Lithium2.2 mEq/LCritical High (> 1.5)
Serum Sodium152 mEq/LHigh

conditionOptions.text: Heat Exhaustion with Normal Lithium Levels

actionOptions.text: Instruct client to reduce salt intake
Administer an extra dose of Lithium

rationale.correct: The client has Dehydration-Induced Lithium Toxicity (c2) (Level 2.2). Lithium is a salt; as the patient lost fluids and salt through sweating, the kidneys retained Lithium instead of excreting it. The priority is to stop the drug (a2) and rehydrate with Normal Saline (a1) to return the patient to an isovolemic state, which will allow the kidneys to flush the lithium. Monitoring sodium/lithium levels (p1) and urine markers (p2) is essential.
clinicalPearls: Lithium and Sodium share transporters in the kidney. If the body is thirsty for salt/water, it will grab Lithium as if it were sodium.
Vigorous exercise, sweating, and diuretic use are major risk factors for Lithium toxicity.

questionTrap.trap: Restricting sodium to treat the high sodium (152) in a lithium patient.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Sodium restriction will worsen Lithium toxicity. Use IV Normal Saline to restore balance and promote lithium excretion.
